<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg/220px-Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg/330px-Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg/440px-Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trump_AVM_opening_ceremony.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a>, then the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">Prime Minister of Turkey</a>, attended the opening of <a href="/wiki/Trump_Towers_Istanbul" title="Trump Towers Istanbul">Trump Towers Istanbul</a> AVM in 2012.</div></div></div>
<p>Before being inaugurated as president, Trump moved his businesses into a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revocable_trust" title="Revocable trust">revocable trust</a> run by his eldest sons and a business associate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPR012018_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPR012018-173">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC041817_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC041817-174">[170]</a></sup> According to ethics experts, this measure did not help avoid conflicts of interest, because Trump continued to profit from his businesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Venook_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-Venook-175">[171]</a></sup> Because Trump continued to have knowledge of how his administration's policies affected his businesses, ethics experts recommended selling the businesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC041817_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC041817-174">[170]</a></sup> Though Trump said he would eschew "new foreign deals", the Trump Organization pursued expansions of its operations in Dubai, Scotland, and the Dominican Republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Venook_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-Venook-175">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pending lawsuits allege that Trump is violating the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domestic_Emoluments_Clause" title="Domestic Emoluments Clause">Domestic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Emoluments_Clause" title="Foreign Emoluments Clause">Foreign Emoluments Clauses</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Constitution" title="U.S. Constitution">U.S. Constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRSRpt_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-CRSRpt-176">[172]</a></sup> The plaintiffs say that Trump's business interests could allow foreign governments to influence him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRSRpt_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-CRSRpt-176">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Venook_175-2"><a href="#cite_note-Venook-175">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaFraniere_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-LaFraniere-177">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Polantz_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-Polantz-178">[174]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a> reported in 2019 that representatives of at least 22 foreign governments, including some facing charges of corruption or human rights abuses, appeared to have spent money at Trump Organization businesses during his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[176]</a></sup> The litigation marks the first time that the Emoluments Clauses have been substantively litigated in court.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRSRpt_176-2"><a href="#cite_note-CRSRpt-176">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Polantz_178-1"><a href="#cite_note-Polantz-178">[174]</a></sup> As president, Trump mocked the Emoluments Clause as "phony".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Venook_175-3"><a href="#cite_note-Venook-175">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_career">Media career</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_career_of_Donald_Trump" title="Media career of Donald Trump">Media career of Donald Trump</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Books">Books</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bibliography_of_Donald_Trump" title="Bibliography of Donald Trump">Bibliography of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Trump has written up to 19 books on business, financial, or political topics, though he has employed ghostwriters to actually write them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[178]</a></sup>  Trump's first book, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Art_of_the_Deal" title="The Art of the Deal">The Art of the Deal</a></i> (1987), was a <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Best_Seller_list" title="The New York Times Best Seller list"><i>New York Times</i> Best Seller</a>. While Trump was credited as co-author, the entire book was <a href="/wiki/Ghostwriter" title="Ghostwriter">ghostwritten</a> by <a href="/wiki/Tony_Schwartz_(author)" title="Tony Schwartz (author)">Tony Schwartz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i>, "The book expanded Trump's renown far beyond New York City, promoting an image of himself as a successful dealmaker and tycoon." Trump has called the book his second favorite, after the Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Film_and_television">Film and television</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_filmography" title="Donald Trump filmography">Donald Trump filmography</a></div>
<p>Trump made <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cameo_appearances" title="Cameo appearances">cameo appearances</a> in eight films and television shows from 1985 to 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlantic_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic-185">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has had a sporadic relationship with the <a href="/wiki/Professional_wrestling" title="Professional wrestling">professional wrestling</a> promotion <a href="/wiki/WWE" title="WWE">WWE</a> (World Wrestling Entertainment) since the late 1980s<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-myth_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-myth-187">[183]</a></sup> and was inducted into the celebrity wing of the <a href="/wiki/WWE_Hall_of_Fame_(2013)" title="WWE Hall of Fame (2013)">WWE Hall of Fame in 2013</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chief_heel_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-chief_heel-188">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting in the 1990s, Trump was a guest about 24 times on the nationally syndicated <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Howard_Stern_Show" title="Howard Stern Show">Howard Stern Show</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKranishFisher2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidx2jUDQAAQBAJpgPA166_166]_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKranishFisher2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidx2jUDQAAQBAJpgPA166_166]-189">[185]</a></sup> He also had his own short-form talk radio program called <i><a href="/wiki/Trumped!" title="Trumped!">Trumped!</a></i> (one to two minutes on weekdays) from 2004 to 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[187]</a></sup> From 2011 until 2015, he was a weekly unpaid guest commentator on <i><a href="/wiki/Fox_%26_Friends" title="Fox &amp; Friends">Fox &amp; Friends</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2003, Trump became the co-producer and host of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Apprentice_(American_TV_series)" title="The Apprentice (American TV series)">The Apprentice</a></i>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reality_show" title="Reality show">reality show</a> in which Trump played the role of a <a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">chief executive</a> and contestants competed for a year of employment at the Trump Organization. Trump eliminated contestants with the <a href="/wiki/Catchphrase" title="Catchphrase">catchphrase</a> "You're fired."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-born_7-17-16_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-born_7-17-16-194">[190]</a></sup> He later co-hosted <i><a href="/wiki/The_Celebrity_Apprentice" title="The Celebrity Apprentice">The Celebrity Apprentice</a></i>, in which celebrities competed to win money for charities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-born_7-17-16_194-1"><a href="#cite_note-born_7-17-16-194">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_career">Political career</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_career_of_Donald_Trump" title="Political career of Donald Trump">Political career of Donald Trump</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_activities_up_to_2015">Political activities up to 2015</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1707" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_and_Bill_Clinton.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump and President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> in June 2000</div></div></div>
<p>Trump's political party affiliation changed numerous times. He registered as a Republican in 1987, a member of the <a href="/wiki/Independence_Party_of_New_York" title="Independence Party of New York">Independence Party</a>, the New York state affiliate of the <a href="/wiki/Reform_Party_of_the_United_States_of_America" title="Reform Party of the United States of America">Reform Party</a>, in 1999,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> a Democrat in 2001, a Republican in 2009, unaffiliated in 2011, and a Republican in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PolitiFact.24.Aug.15_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-PolitiFact.24.Aug.15-196">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1987, Trump placed full-page advertisements in three major newspapers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hint_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-hint-197">[193]</a></sup> advocating peace in Central America, accelerated nuclear disarmament talks with the Soviet Union, and reduction of the federal budget deficit by making American allies pay "their fair share" for military defense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[194]</a></sup> He ruled out running for local office but not for the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hint_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-hint-197">[193]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2000_presidential_campaign">2000 presidential campaign</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2000_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2000 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2000 presidential campaign</a></div>
<p>Trump ran in the California and Michigan primaries for nomination as the <a href="/wiki/Reform_Party_of_the_United_States_of_America" title="Reform Party of the United States of America">Reform Party</a> candidate for the 2000 presidential election but withdrew from the race in February 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Winger-111225_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-Winger-111225-199">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup> A July 1999 poll matching him against likely Republican nominee <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> and likely Democratic nominee <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a> showed Trump with seven percent support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[198]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2012_presidential_speculation">2012 presidential speculation</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_speaking_at_CPAC_2011_by_Mark_Taylor.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump speaking at CPAC 2011</div></div></div>
<p>Trump speculated about running against President Barack Obama in <a href="/wiki/2012_United_States_presidential_election" title="2012 United States presidential election">the 2012 election</a>, making his first speaking appearance at the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Political_Action_Conference" title="Conservative Political Action Conference">Conservative Political Action Conference</a> (CPAC) in February 2011 and giving speeches in early primary states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McA_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-McA-203">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[200]</a></sup> In May 2011 he announced he would not run,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McA_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-McA-203">[199]</a></sup> and he endorsed <a href="/wiki/Mitt_Romney" title="Mitt Romney">Mitt Romney</a> in February 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's presidential ambitions were generally not taken seriously at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[202]</a></sup> Before the 2016 election, <i>The New York Times</i> speculated that Trump "accelerated his ferocious efforts to gain stature within the political world" after Obama lampooned him at the <a href="/wiki/White_House_Correspondents%27_Association" title="White House Correspondents' Association">White House Correspondents' Association</a> Dinner in April 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, the superintendent of the New York Military Academy at the time, Jeffrey Coverdale, ordered the headmaster of the school, Evan Jones, to give him Trump's academic records so he could keep them secret, according to Jones. Coverdale confirmed that he had been asked to hand the records over to members of the school's board of trustees who were Trump's friends, but he refused to and instead sealed them on campus. The incident reportedly happened days after Trump demanded the release of Obama's academic records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[204]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2013.E2.80.932015"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2013–2015">2013–2015</span></h4>
<p>In 2013, Trump spoke at CPAC again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPAC1_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-CPAC1-209">[205]</a></sup> He railed against illegal immigration, bemoaned Obama's "unprecedented media protection", advised against harming Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security, and suggested the government "take" Iraq's oil and use the proceeds to pay a million dollars each to families of dead soldiers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[207]</a></sup> He spent over $1 million that year to research a possible 2016 candidacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYPost2016_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYPost2016-212">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2013, New York Republicans circulated a memo suggesting that Trump <a href="/wiki/2014_New_York_gubernatorial_election" title="2014 New York gubernatorial election">run for governor</a> in 2014 against <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Cuomo" title="Andrew Cuomo">Andrew Cuomo</a>. Trump responded that while New York had problems and its taxes were too high, he was not interested in the governorship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[209]</a></sup> A poll showed Trump losing to the more popular Cuomo by 37 points in a hypothetical election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's attorney <a href="/wiki/Michael_Cohen_(lawyer)" title="Michael Cohen (lawyer)">Michael Cohen</a> said that he sent letters to the New York Military Academy and Fordham in May 2015, threatening legal action if the schools ever released Trump's grades or SAT scores. Fordham confirmed receipt of the letter as well as a phone call from a member of the Trump team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[211]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2016_presidential_campaign">2016 presidential campaign</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2016_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_primaries">Republican primaries</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/2016_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2016 Republican Party presidential primaries">2016 Republican Party presidential primaries</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally,_Laconia,_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg"><img alt='Trump speaking behind a brown wooden podium, wearing a dark blue suit and a red tie. The podium sports a blue "TRUMP" sign.' class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5792" data-file-width="8688" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally%2C_Laconia%2C_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally%2C_Laconia%2C_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally%2C_Laconia%2C_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally%2C_Laconia%2C_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally%2C_Laconia%2C_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally%2C_Laconia%2C_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_Laconia_Rally,_Laconia,_NH_4_by_Michael_Vadon_July_16_2015_19.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump campaigning in <a href="/wiki/Laconia,_New_Hampshire" title="Laconia, New Hampshire">Laconia, New Hampshire</a>, July 2015</div></div></div>
<p>On June 16, 2015, Trump announced his candidacy for President of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-spectacle_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-spectacle-216">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[213]</a></sup> His campaign was initially not taken seriously by political analysts, but he quickly rose to the top of opinion polls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p>On <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2016#March_1,_2016:_Super_Tuesday" title="Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016">Super Tuesday</a>, Trump received the most votes, and he remained the front-runner throughout the primaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> After a landslide win in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indiana_Republican_primary,_2016" title="Indiana Republican primary, 2016">Indiana</a> on May 3, 2016 – which prompted the remaining candidates Cruz and <a href="/wiki/John_Kasich" title="John Kasich">John Kasich</a> to suspend their presidential campaigns – <a href="/wiki/Republican_National_Committee" title="Republican National Committee">RNC</a> chairman <a href="/wiki/Reince_Priebus" title="Reince Priebus">Reince Priebus</a> declared Trump the presumptive Republican nominee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politico_priebus_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-politico_priebus-220">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="General_election_campaign">General election campaign</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election#General_election_campaign" title="2016 United States presidential election">2016 United States presidential election § General election campaign</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a> had a significant lead over Trump in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nationwide_opinion_polling_for_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2016" title="Nationwide opinion polling for the United States presidential election, 2016">national polls</a> throughout most of 2016. In early July, her lead narrowed in national polling averages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg"><img alt='Donald Trump and his running mate for vice president, Mike Pence. They appear to be standing in front of a huge screen with the colors of the American flag displayed on it. Trump is at the left, facing toward the viewer and making "thumbs-up" gestures. Pence is at right, facing Trump and clapping.' class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2288" data-file-width="3794" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_and_Mike_Pence_RNC_July_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Candidate Trump and running mate <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">Mike Pence</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Republican_National_Convention" title="Republican National Convention">Republican National Convention</a>, July 2016</div></div></div>
<p>On July 15, 2016, Trump announced his selection of Indiana governor <a href="/wiki/Mike_Pence" title="Mike Pence">Mike Pence</a> as his vice presidential running mate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[219]</a></sup> Four days later, the two were officially nominated by the Republican Party at the Republican National Convention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump and Clinton faced off in <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_debates" title="2016 United States presidential debates">three presidential debates</a> in September and October 2016. Trump's refusal to say whether he would accept the result of the election, regardless of the outcome, drew particular attention, with some saying it undermined democracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_positions">Political positions</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_positions_of_Donald_Trump" title="Political positions of Donald Trump">Political positions of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Trump's campaign platform emphasized renegotiating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93China_relations" title="U.S.–China relations">U.S.–China relations</a> and free trade agreements such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NAFTA" title="NAFTA">NAFTA</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a>, strongly enforcing immigration laws, and building <a href="/wiki/Trump_wall" title="Trump wall">a new wall</a> along the U.S.–Mexico border. His other campaign positions included pursuing <a href="/wiki/Energy_independence" title="Energy independence">energy independence</a> while opposing climate change regulations such as the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Power_Plan" title="Clean Power Plan">Clean Power Plan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a>, modernizing and expediting <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Veterans_Affairs#Benefits" title="United States Department of Veterans Affairs">services for veterans</a>, repealing and replacing the <a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">Affordable Care Act</a>, abolishing <a href="/wiki/Common_Core" title="Common Core">Common Core</a> education standards, <a href="/wiki/Infrastructure-based_development" title="Infrastructure-based development">investing in infrastructure</a>, simplifying the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Code" title="Internal Revenue Code">tax code</a> while reducing taxes for all economic classes, and imposing <a href="/wiki/Tariff" title="Tariff">tariffs</a> on imports by companies that offshore jobs. During the campaign, he also advocated a largely <a href="/wiki/United_States_non-interventionism" title="United States non-interventionism">non-interventionist</a> approach to foreign policy while increasing military spending, extreme vetting or banning immigrants from Muslim-majority countries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup> to pre-empt domestic Islamic terrorism, and aggressive military action against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant</a>. During the campaign Trump repeatedly called <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> "obsolete".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's political positions and rhetoric are <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_populism" title="Right-wing populism">right-wing populist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-230">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup> He supported or leaned toward varying political positions over time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davida.fahrenthold_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-davida.fahrenthold-233">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thehillFLIP_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-thehillFLIP-234">[230]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Politico" title="Politico">Politico</a></i> has described his positions as "eclectic, improvisational and often contradictory",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-real_Donald_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-real_Donald-235">[231]</a></sup> while NBC News counted "141 distinct shifts on 23 major issues" during his campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nbcnews.com_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-nbcnews.com-236">[232]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Campaign_rhetoric">Campaign rhetoric</span></h4>
<p>In his campaign, Trump said he disdained <a href="/wiki/Political_correctness" title="Political correctness">political correctness</a> and frequently made claims of <a href="/wiki/Media_bias" title="Media bias">media bias</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Walsh-160724_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-Walsh-160724-237">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blake-150706_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blake-150706-239">[235]</a></sup> His fame and provocative statements earned him an unprecedented amount of <a href="/wiki/Earned_media" title="Earned media">free media coverage</a>, elevating his standing in the Republican primaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cillizza-160614_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cillizza-160614-240">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump made a record number of false statements compared to other candidates;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whoppers_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-whoppers-241">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-year_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-year-242">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wapo-false_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-wapo-false-243">[239]</a></sup> the press reported on his campaign lies and falsehoods, with the <i>Los Angeles Times</i> saying, "Never in modern presidential politics has a major candidate made false statements as routinely as Trump has."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[240]</a></sup> His campaign statements were often opaque or suggestive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump adopted the phrase "truthful hyperbole", coined by his ghostwriter <a href="/wiki/Tony_Schwartz_(author)" title="Tony Schwartz (author)">Tony Schwartz</a>, to describe his public speaking style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters-20150828_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuters-20150828-246">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Konnikova_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-Konnikova-247">[243]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Support_from_the_far_right">Support from the far right</span></h4>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Michael_Barkun" title="Michael Barkun">Michael Barkun</a>, the Trump campaign was remarkable for bringing fringe ideas, beliefs, and organizations into the mainstream.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup> During his presidential campaign, Trump was accused of pandering to white supremacists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup> He retweeted open racists,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup> and repeatedly refused to condemn <a href="/wiki/David_Duke" title="David Duke">David Duke</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan" title="Ku Klux Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a> or white supremacists, in an interview on CNN's <i><a href="/wiki/State_of_the_Union_(American_TV_program)" title="State of the Union (American TV program)">State of the Union</a></i>, saying he would first need to "do research" because he knew nothing about Duke or white supremacists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[251]</a></sup> Duke himself enthusiastically supported Trump throughout the 2016 primary and election, and has said he and like-minded people voted for Trump because of his promises to "take our country back".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>After repeated questioning by reporters, Trump said he disavowed Duke and the Klan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnnduke_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnnduke-258">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Alt-right" title="Alt-right">alt-right</a> movement coalesced around and enthusiastically supported Trump's candidacy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WPechoes_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-WPechoes-259">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup> due in part to its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Opposition_to_multiculturalism" title="Opposition to multiculturalism">opposition to multiculturalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_immigration" title="Opposition to immigration">immigration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[257]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNNexplained_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNNexplained-262">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ft_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-ft-263">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2016, he appointed <a href="/wiki/Steve_Bannon" title="Steve Bannon">Steve Bannon</a> – the executive chairman of <a href="/wiki/Breitbart_News" title="Breitbart News">Breitbart News</a> – as his campaign CEO; Bannon described Breitbart News as "the platform for the alt-right".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[260]</a></sup> In an interview days after the election, Trump condemned supporters who celebrated his victory with Nazi salutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC.Disavows_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC.Disavows-265">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[262]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Financial_disclosures">Financial disclosures</span></h4>
<p>As a candidate, Trump's FEC-required reports listed assets above $1.4 billion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yahoo_News_FEC_63-1"><a href="#cite_note-Yahoo_News_FEC-63">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[263]</a></sup> and outstanding debts of at least $315 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn-20160519_114-1"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-20160519-114">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has not released <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Donald_Trump%27s_tax_returns" title="Donald Trump's tax returns">his tax returns</a>, contrary to the practice of every major candidate since 1976 and his promises in 2014 and 2015 to do so if he ran for office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rappeport_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rappeport-268">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[265]</a></sup> He said his tax returns were being audited (in actuality, audits do not prevent release of tax returns), and his lawyers had advised him against releasing them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNNtax26Feb_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNNtax26Feb-270">[266]</a></sup> Trump has told the press his tax rate is none of their business, and that he tries to pay "as little tax as possible".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2016, portions of Trump's state filings for 1995 were leaked to a reporter from <i>The New York Times</i>. They show that Trump had declared a loss of $916 million that year, which could have let him avoid taxes for up to 18 years. During the second presidential debate, Trump acknowledged using the deduction, but declined to provide details such as the specific years it was applied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-20161010_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-20161010-272">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 14, 2017, the first two pages of Trump's 2005 federal income tax returns were leaked to <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a>. The document states that Trump had a gross adjusted income of $150 million and paid $38 million in federal taxes. The White House confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-taxes_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-taxes-273">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hill-taxes_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-hill-taxes-274">[270]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_Ways_and_Means_Committee" title="House Ways and Means Committee">House Ways and Means Committee</a> sought Trump's personal and business tax returns from 2013 to 2018 from the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service" title="Internal Revenue Service">Internal Revenue Service</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> Treasury Secretary <a href="/wiki/Steven_Mnuchin" title="Steven Mnuchin">Steven Mnuchin</a> refused to turn over the documents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[274]</a></sup> and ultimately defied a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congressional_subpoena" title="Congressional subpoena">subpoena issued by the committee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup> A fall 2018 draft IRS legal memo asserted that tax returns must be provided to Congress upon request, unless a president invokes executive privilege, contradicting the administration's position.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[277]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Election_to_the_presidency">Election to the presidency</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election" title="2016 United States presidential election">2016 United States presidential election</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2016.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/ElectoralCollege2016.svg/290px-ElectoralCollege2016.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/ElectoralCollege2016.svg/435px-ElectoralCollege2016.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/ElectoralCollege2016.svg/580px-ElectoralCollege2016.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2016.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>2016 electoral vote results</div></div></div>
<p>On November 8, 2016, Trump received 306 pledged <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(United_States)" title="Electoral College (United States)">electoral votes</a> versus 232 for Clinton. The official counts were 304 and 227 respectively, after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Faithless_electors_in_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2016" title="Faithless electors in the United States presidential election, 2016">defections on both sides</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[278]</a></sup> Trump received nearly 2.9 million fewer popular votes than Clinton, which made him the fifth person to be elected president <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_elections_in_which_the_winner_lost_the_popular_vote" title="United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote">while losing the popular vote</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[e]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[281]</a></sup> Clinton was ahead nationwide, with 65,853,514 votes (<span data-sort-value="7001481845780759093♠" style="display:none"></span>48.18%) compared to Trump's 62,984,828 votes (<span data-sort-value="7001460855796148360♠" style="display:none"></span>46.09%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[282]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JANUS-T%C3%AAte-%C3%A0-T%C3%AAte-_Sitting_President_%26_President-elect,_Barack_Obama_%26_Donald_Trump_squatting_next_to_each_other_on_arm-chairs_in_the_Oval_Office_on_November_10th_2016._(31196987133).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/JANUS-T%C3%AAte-%C3%A0-T%C3%AAte-_Sitting_President_%26_President-elect%2C_Barack_Obama_%26_Donald_Trump_squatting_next_to_each_other_on_arm-chairs_in_the_Oval_Office_on_November_10th_2016._%2831196987133%29.jpg/200px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/JANUS-T%C3%AAte-%C3%A0-T%C3%AAte-_Sitting_President_%26_President-elect%2C_Barack_Obama_%26_Donald_Trump_squatting_next_to_each_other_on_arm-chairs_in_the_Oval_Office_on_November_10th_2016._%2831196987133%29.jpg/300px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/JANUS-T%C3%AAte-%C3%A0-T%C3%AAte-_Sitting_President_%26_President-elect%2C_Barack_Obama_%26_Donald_Trump_squatting_next_to_each_other_on_arm-chairs_in_the_Oval_Office_on_November_10th_2016._%2831196987133%29.jpg/400px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JANUS-T%C3%AAte-%C3%A0-T%C3%AAte-_Sitting_President_%26_President-elect,_Barack_Obama_%26_Donald_Trump_squatting_next_to_each_other_on_arm-chairs_in_the_Oval_Office_on_November_10th_2016._(31196987133).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Obama</a> and president-elect Trump on November 10, 2016</div></div></div>
<p>Trump's victory was a political upset.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maxwell_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-Maxwell-288">[283]</a></sup> Polls had consistently shown Clinton with a <a href="/wiki/Nationwide_opinion_polling_for_the_2016_United_States_presidential_election" title="Nationwide opinion polling for the 2016 United States presidential election">nationwide</a> – though diminishing – lead, as well as an advantage in most of the <a href="/wiki/Statewide_opinion_polling_for_the_2016_United_States_presidential_election" title="Statewide opinion polling for the 2016 United States presidential election">competitive states</a>. Trump's support had been modestly underestimated, while Clinton's had been overestimated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[284]</a></sup> The polls were relatively accurate,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[285]</a></sup> but media outlets and pundits alike showed overconfidence in a Clinton victory despite a large number of undecided voters and a favorable concentration of Trump's core constituencies in competitive states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump won 30 states; included were <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wisconsin" title="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>, which had been part of what was considered a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blue_wall_(politics)" title="Blue wall (politics)">blue wall</a> of Democratic strongholds since the 1990s. Clinton won 20 states and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/District_of_Columbia" title="District of Columbia">District of Columbia</a>. Trump's victory marked the return of an <a href="/wiki/Divided_government_in_the_United_States" title="Divided government in the United States">undivided</a> Republican government – a Republican White House combined with Republican control of both chambers of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age" title="List of presidents of the United States by age">oldest person to take office</a> as president at inauguration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oldest_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-oldest-2">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-age_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-age-3">[b]</a></sup> He is also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_by_previous_experience" title="List of Presidents of the United States by previous experience">the first president</a> who did not serve in the military or hold any government office prior to becoming president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voxexp_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-voxexp-294">[289]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Protests">Protests</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Protests_against_Donald_Trump" title="Protests against Donald Trump">Protests against Donald Trump</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Women%27s_March_on_Washington_(32593123745).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3550" data-file-width="5325" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Women%27s_March_on_Washington_%2832593123745%29.jpg/220px-Women%27s_March_on_Washington_%2832593123745%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Women%27s_March_on_Washington_%2832593123745%29.jpg/330px-Women%27s_March_on_Washington_%2832593123745%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Women%27s_March_on_Washington_%2832593123745%29.jpg/440px-Women%27s_March_on_Washington_%2832593123745%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Women%27s_March_on_Washington_(32593123745).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/2017_Women%27s_March" title="2017 Women's March">Women's March</a> in Washington on January 21, 2017, a day after Trump's inauguration</div></div></div>
<p>Some rallies during the primary season were accompanied by protests or violence, both inside and outside the venues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[292]</a></sup> Trump's election victory sparked protests across the United States, in opposition to his policies and his inflammatory statements. Trump initially tweeted that these were "professional protesters, incited by the media" and "unfair", but later "Love the fact that the small groups of protesters last night have passion for our great country."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the weeks following Trump's inauguration, massive anti-Trump demonstrations took place, such as the <a href="/wiki/2017_Women%27s_March" title="2017 Women's March">Women's Marches</a>, which gathered 2.6 million people worldwide,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAToday01a_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday01a-300">[295]</a></sup> including 500,000 in Washington alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[296]</a></sup> Marches against his <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_13769" title="Executive Order 13769">travel ban</a> began across the country on January 29, 2017, just nine days after his inauguration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Presidency_.282017.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency_(2017–present)">Presidency (2017–present)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Donald_Trump" title="Presidency of Donald Trump">Presidency of Donald Trump</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide to this subject, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Donald_Trump_presidency" title="Timeline of the Donald Trump presidency">Timeline of the Donald Trump presidency</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_actions">Early actions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Donald_Trump" title="Presidential transition of Donald Trump">Presidential transition of Donald Trump</a> and <a href="/wiki/First_100_days_of_Donald_Trump%27s_presidency" title="First 100 days of Donald Trump's presidency">First 100 days of Donald Trump's presidency</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2576" data-file-width="3863" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg/220px-58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg/330px-58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg/440px-58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:58th_Presidential_Inaugural_Ceremony_170120-D-BP749-1327.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump during his inauguration in 2017. From left, <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Schumer" title="Chuck Schumer">Chuck Schumer</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump" title="Inauguration of Donald Trump">Trump was inaugurated</a> as the 45th president of the United States on January 20, 2017. During his first week in office, he signed <a href="/wiki/List_of_executive_actions_by_Donald_Trump#Executive_orders" title="List of executive actions by Donald Trump">six executive orders</a>: interim procedures in anticipation of repealing the <a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">Affordable Care Act</a> ("Obamacare"), withdrawal from the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a> negotiations, reinstatement of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Policy" title="Mexico City Policy">Mexico City Policy</a>, unlocking the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Keystone_XL" title="Keystone XL">Keystone XL</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dakota_Access_Pipeline" title="Dakota Access Pipeline">Dakota Access Pipeline</a> construction projects, reinforcing border security, and beginning the planning and design process to construct a <a href="/wiki/Trump_wall" title="Trump wall">wall along the U.S. border with Mexico</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exec-summary_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-exec-summary-303">[298]</a></sup>
</p><p>Upon inauguration, Trump stated that he delegated the management of his real estate business to his sons Eric and Donald Jr, with no resolution of questions about potential conflicts of interest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[299]</a></sup> His daughter Ivanka and her husband <a href="/wiki/Jared_Kushner" title="Jared Kushner">Jared Kushner</a> became <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assistant_to_the_President" title="Assistant to the President">Assistant to the President</a> and <a href="/wiki/Senior_Advisor_to_the_President_of_the_United_States" title="Senior Advisor to the President of the United States">Senior Advisor to the President</a>, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[301]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_policy">Domestic policy</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy_and_trade">Economy and trade</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_policy_of_Donald_Trump" title="Economic policy of Donald Trump">Economic policy of Donald Trump</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act_of_2017" title="Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017">Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trump_tariffs" title="Trump tariffs">Trump tariffs</a></div>
<p>The period of economic expansion that began in June 2009 continued until February 2020, when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coronavirus_recession" title="Coronavirus recession">the COVID-19 recession</a> began.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-recession_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-recession-307">[302]</a></sup> Throughout his presidency, Trump mischaracterized the economy as the best in American history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greatesteconomy_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-greatesteconomy-308">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2017, Trump signed <a href="/wiki/Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act_of_2017" title="Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017">tax legislation</a> that permanently cut the corporate tax rate to 21 percent, lowered personal income tax rates until 2025, increased child tax credits, doubled the <a href="/wiki/Estate_tax_in_the_United_States" title="Estate tax in the United States">estate tax</a> exemption to $11.2 million, and limited the state and local tax deduction to $10,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[304]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_(33998674940)_(cropped2).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1315" data-file-width="1780" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_%2833998674940%29_%28cropped2%29.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_%2833998674940%29_%28cropped2%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_%2833998674940%29_%28cropped2%29.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_%2833998674940%29_%28cropped2%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_%2833998674940%29_%28cropped2%29.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_%2833998674940%29_%28cropped2%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_in_Ypsilanti_(33998674940)_(cropped2).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump speaks to automobile workers in Michigan, March 2017</div></div></div>
<p>Trump is a skeptic of multilateral trade agreements, believing they incentivize unfair commercial practices, favoring bilateral trade agreements, as they allow one party to withdraw if the other party is believed to be behaving unfairly. Trump adopted his current skepticism of trade liberalization in the 1980s, and sharply criticized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NAFTA" title="NAFTA">NAFTA</a> during the Republican primary campaign in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[307]</a></sup> He withdrew the U.S. from the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a> (TPP) negotiations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[308]</a></sup> imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inman_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-Inman-314">[309]</a></sup> and launched a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war" title="China–United States trade war">trade war</a> with China by sharply increasing tariffs on 818 categories (worth $50 billion) of Chinese goods imported into the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-316">[311]</a></sup> On several occasions, Trump has said incorrectly that these import tariffs are paid by China into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Treasury" title="U.S. Treasury">U.S. Treasury</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newburger-190512_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newburger-190512-317">[312]</a></sup> Although Trump pledged during his 2016 campaign to significantly reduce the U.S.'s large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_deficits" title="Trade deficits">trade deficits</a>, the U.S. trade deficit reached its highest level in 12 years under his administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[313]</a></sup> Following a 2017–2018 renegotiation, Trump signed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States-Mexico-Canada_Agreement" title="United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement">United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement</a> (USMCA) as the successor to NAFTA on January 29, 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[314]</a></sup> The revised trade deal became effective on July 1, 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[315]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite a campaign promise to eliminate the national debt in eight years, Trump as president has approved large increases in government spending, as well as the 2017 tax cut. As a result, the American government's budget deficit has increased by almost 50%, to nearly $1<span class="nowrap"> </span>trillion in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[316]</a></sup> In 2016, the year before Trump took office, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._national_debt" title="U.S. national debt">U.S. national debt</a> was around $19<span class="nowrap"> </span>trillion; by mid-2020, it had increased to $26<span class="nowrap"> </span>trillion under the Trump administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[317]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2020, the official unemployment rate rose to 14.7% due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This was an underestimation of the actual unemployment rate, but still was the highest level of unemployment since 1939.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p>Analysis published by <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> in October 2020 found the trade war Trump initiated in early 2018 did not achieve the primary objective of reviving American manufacturing, nor did it result in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reshoring" title="Reshoring">reshoring</a> of factory production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[319]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_and_climate">Energy and climate</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_Donald_Trump_administration" title="Environmental policy of the Donald Trump administration">Environmental policy of the Donald Trump administration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States" title="Climate change in the United States">Climate change in the United States</a></div>
<p>Trump rejects the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_consensus_on_climate_change" title="Scientific consensus on climate change">scientific consensus on climate change</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ParkerDavenport_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-ParkerDavenport-325">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[321]</a></sup> He made large budget cuts to programs that research renewable energy and rolled back Obama-era policies directed at curbing climate change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[322]</a></sup> In June 2017, Trump announced <a href="/wiki/United_States_withdrawal_from_the_Paris_Agreement" title="United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement">the withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement</a>, making the U.S. the only nation in the world to not ratify the agreement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[323]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has rolled back federal regulations aimed at curbing <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gas</a> emissions, air pollution, water pollution, and the usage of toxic substances. One example is the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Power_Plan" title="Clean Power Plan">Clean Power Plan</a>. He relaxed environmental standards for federal infrastructure projects, while expanding permitted areas for drilling and resource extraction, such as allowing <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Refuge_drilling_controversy" title="Arctic Refuge drilling controversy">drilling in the Arctic Refuge</a>. Trump also weakened protections for animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[324]</a></sup> Trump's energy policies aimed to boost the production and exports of coal, oil, and natural gas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[325]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Deregulation">Deregulation</span></h4>
<p>During his presidency, Trump has <a href="/wiki/Deregulation" title="Deregulation">dismantled many federal regulations</a> on health, labor, and the environment, among other topics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[326]</a></sup> Trump signed 15 <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Review_Act" title="Congressional Review Act">Congressional Review Act</a> resolutions repealing federal regulations, becoming the second president to sign a CRA resolution, and the first president to sign more than one CRA resolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[327]</a></sup> During his first six weeks in office, he delayed, suspended or reversed ninety federal regulations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 30, 2017, Trump signed <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_13771" title="Executive Order 13771">Executive Order 13771</a>, which directed that for every new regulation administrative agencies issue "at least two prior regulations be identified for elimination".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[330]</a></sup> Agency defenders expressed opposition to Trump's criticisms, saying the bureaucracy exists to protect people against well-organized, well-funded interest groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcalabresi_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-mcalabresi-336">[331]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h4>
<p>During his campaign, Trump vowed to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Efforts_to_repeal_the_Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Efforts to repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">repeal</a> and replace the <a href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">Affordable Care Act</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kodjak_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kodjak-337">[332]</a></sup> and urged Congress to do so. In May 2017, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives passed a <a href="/wiki/American_Health_Care_Act_of_2017" title="American Health Care Act of 2017">bill to repeal the ACA</a> in a party-line vote,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[333]</a></sup> but repeal proposals were narrowly voted down in the Senate after three Republicans joined all Democrats in opposing it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump scaled back the implementation of the ACA through <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_13765" title="Executive Order 13765">Executive Orders 13765</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[335]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_13813" title="Executive Order 13813">13813</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[336]</a></sup> Trump has expressed a desire to "let Obamacare fail"; his administration cut the ACA <a href="/wiki/Annual_enrollment" title="Annual enrollment">enrollment period</a> in half and drastically reduced funding for advertising and other ways to encourage enrollment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jeffrey_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jeffrey-343">[338]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act_of_2017" title="Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017">2017 tax bill</a> signed by Trump effectively repealed the ACA's <a href="/wiki/Individual_shared_responsibility_provision" title="Individual shared responsibility provision">individual health insurance mandate</a> in 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[339]</a></sup> and a budget bill Trump signed in 2019 repealed the <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_insurance_plan" title="Cadillac insurance plan">Cadillac plan tax</a>, medical device tax, and <a href="/wiki/Tanning_tax" title="Tanning tax">tanning tax</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CadillacRepealed_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-CadillacRepealed-345">[340]</a></sup> As president, Trump has falsely claimed he saved the coverage of pre-existing conditions provided by the ACA;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[341]</a></sup> in fact, the Trump administration has <a href="/wiki/California_v._Texas" title="California v. Texas">joined a lawsuit</a> seeking to strike down the entire ACA, including protections for those with pre-existing conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StolbergACA_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-StolbergACA-347">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[343]</a></sup> If successful, the lawsuit would eliminate <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance_coverage_in_the_United_States" title="Health insurance coverage in the United States">health insurance coverage</a> for up to 23 million Americans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StolbergACA_347-1"><a href="#cite_note-StolbergACA-347">[342]</a></sup> As a 2016 candidate, Trump promised to protect funding for Medicare and other social safety-net programs, but in January 2020 he suggested he was willing to consider cuts to such programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[344]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_issues">Social issues</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Social_policy_of_Donald_Trump" title="Social policy of Donald Trump">Social policy of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Trump favored modifying the 2016 Republican platform opposing abortion, to allow for exceptions in cases of rape, incest, and circumstances endangering the health of the mother.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[345]</a></sup> He has said he is committed to appointing "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pro-life" title="Pro-life">pro-life</a>" justices, pledging in 2016 to appoint justices who would "automatically" overturn <i><a href="/wiki/Roe_v._Wade" title="Roe v. Wade">Roe v. Wade</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[346]</a></sup> He says he personally supports "traditional marriage" but considers the <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_United_States" title="Same-sex marriage in the United States">nationwide legality</a> of <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a> a "settled" issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60min_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-60min-352">[347]</a></sup> In March 2017, the Trump administration rolled back key components of the Obama administration's workplace protections against discrimination of LGBT people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBCNews_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-NBCNews-353">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump says he is <a href="/wiki/Gun_politics_in_the_United_States" title="Gun politics in the United States">opposed</a> to <a href="/wiki/Gun_control" title="Gun control">gun control</a> in general, although his views have shifted over time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[349]</a></sup> After several <a href="/wiki/Mass_shootings_in_the_United_States" title="Mass shootings in the United States">mass shootings</a> during his term, Trump initially said he would propose legislation to curtail gun violence, but this was abandoned in November 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[350]</a></sup> The Trump administration has taken an <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_policy_of_the_Donald_Trump_administration" title="Cannabis policy of the Donald Trump administration">anti-marijuana position</a>, revoking <a href="/wiki/Cole_Memorandum" title="Cole Memorandum">Obama-era policies</a> that provided protections for states that legalized marijuana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>Long favoring <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States" title="Capital punishment in the United States">capital punishment</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cop_killers_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cop_killers-357">[352]</a></sup> Trump approved the first <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_by_the_United_States_federal_government" title="Capital punishment by the United States federal government">federal execution</a> in 17 years in July 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GersteinFirst_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-GersteinFirst-358">[353]</a></sup> Five more federal prisoners were executed, making the total number of federal executions under Trump higher than all of his predecessors combined going back to 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[354]</a></sup> In 2016, Trump said he supported the use of interrogation torture methods such as <a href="/wiki/Waterboarding" title="Waterboarding">waterboarding</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theguardian.com_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-theguardian.com-360">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABC_News_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-ABC_News-361">[356]</a></sup> but later appeared to recant this due to the opposition of Defense Secretary <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Mattis" title="James Mattis">James Mattis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[357]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pardons_and_commutations">Pardons and commutations</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_people_granted_executive_clemency_by_Donald_Trump" title="List of people granted executive clemency by Donald Trump">List of people granted executive clemency by Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Most of Trump's pardons were granted to people with personal or political connections to him, analyzed <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Law_School" title="Harvard Law School">Harvard Law School</a> professor <a href="/wiki/Jack_Goldsmith" title="Jack Goldsmith">Jack Goldsmith</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ballhaus_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ballhaus-363">[358]</a></sup> In his term, Trump sidestepped regular Department of Justice procedures for considering pardons, instead he often entertained pardon requests from his associates or from celebrities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ballhaus_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ballhaus-363">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017, Trump pardoned former Arizona sheriff <a href="/wiki/Joe_Arpaio" title="Joe Arpaio">Joe Arpaio</a> who was convicted of <a href="/wiki/Contempt_of_court" title="Contempt of court">contempt of court</a> for disobeying a court order to halt the <a href="/wiki/Racial_profiling" title="Racial profiling">racial profiling</a> of Latinos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[359]</a></sup> In 2018, Trump pardoned former Navy sailor <a href="/wiki/Kristian_Saucier" title="Kristian Saucier">Kristian Saucier</a>, who was convicted of taking classified photographs of a submarine;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[360]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Scooter_Libby" title="Scooter Libby">Scooter Libby</a>, a political aide to former vice president <a href="/wiki/Dick_Cheney" title="Dick Cheney">Dick Cheney</a>, who was convicted of obstruction of justice, <a href="/wiki/Perjury" title="Perjury">perjury</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Making_false_statements" title="Making false statements">making false statements</a> to the FBI;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[361]</a></sup> conservative commentator <a href="/wiki/Dinesh_D%27Souza" title="Dinesh D'Souza">Dinesh D'Souza</a>, who had made illegal political campaign contributions;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[362]</a></sup> and he commuted the life sentence of <a href="/wiki/Alice_Marie_Johnson" title="Alice Marie Johnson">Alice Marie Johnson</a>, a non-violent drug trafficking offender, following a request by celebrity <a href="/wiki/Kim_Kardashian" title="Kim Kardashian">Kim Kardashian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[363]</a></sup> In February 2020, Trump pardoned white-collar criminals <a href="/wiki/Michael_Milken" title="Michael Milken">Michael Milken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Kerik" title="Bernard Kerik">Bernard Kerik</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Edward_J._DeBartolo_Jr." title="Edward J. DeBartolo Jr.">Edward J. DeBartolo Jr.</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Commutation_(law)" title="Commutation (law)">commuted</a> former Illinois governor <a href="/wiki/Rod_Blagojevich" title="Rod Blagojevich">Rod Blagojevich</a>'s 14-year corruption sentence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Commutation_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-Commutation-369">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[365]</a></sup> Trump in 2019 pardoned or reversed the sentences of three American soldiers convicted or accused of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_crimes" title="War crimes">war crimes</a> in Afghanistan or Iraq;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[366]</a></sup> then in 2020 he pardoned four <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academi" title="Academi">Blackwater</a> mercenaries convicted of killing Iraqi civilians in 2007's <a href="/wiki/Nisour_Square_massacre" title="Nisour Square massacre">Nisour Square massacre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blackwater_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blackwater-372">[367]</a></sup>
