</p><p>The second volume of the Mueller report dealt with possible obstruction of justice by Trump.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WaPoLays_755-0"><a href="#cite_note-WaPoLays-755">[750]</a></sup> The report did not exonerate Trump of obstruction inasmuch as investigators were not confident of his innocence after examining his intent and actions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FactCheck11_756-0"><a href="#cite_note-FactCheck11-756">[751]</a></sup> Investigators decided they could not "apply an approach that could potentially result in a judgment that the President committed crimes" as an <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Legal_Counsel" title="Office of Legal Counsel">Office of Legal Counsel</a> opinion stated that a sitting president could not be indicted, and investigators would not accuse him of a crime when he cannot clear his name in court.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-757"><a href="#cite_note-757">[752]</a></sup> The report concluded that Congress, having the authority to take action against a president for wrongdoing, "may apply the obstruction laws".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-APdilemma_758-0"><a href="#cite_note-APdilemma-758">[753]</a></sup> Congress subsequently launched an <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_inquiry_against_Donald_Trump" title="Impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump">impeachment inquiry</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Trump%E2%80%93Ukraine_scandal" title="Trump–Ukraine scandal">Trump–Ukraine scandal</a>, albeit it ultimately did not press charges related to the Mueller investigation.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Associates">Associates</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Criminal_charges_brought_in_the_Special_Counsel_investigation_(2017%E2%80%932019)" title="Criminal charges brought in the Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)">Criminal charges brought in the Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)</a></div>
<p>In August 2018, former Trump campaign chairman <a href="/wiki/Paul_Manafort" title="Paul Manafort">Paul Manafort</a> was <a href="/wiki/Trials_of_Paul_Manafort" title="Trials of Paul Manafort">convicted</a> on eight felony counts of false tax filing and bank fraud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-759"><a href="#cite_note-759">[754]</a></sup> Trump said he felt very badly for Manafort and praised him for resisting the pressure to make a deal with prosecutors. According to <a href="/wiki/Rudy_Giuliani" title="Rudy Giuliani">Rudy Giuliani</a>, Trump's personal attorney, Trump had sought advice about pardoning Manafort but was counseled against it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Leonnig823_760-0"><a href="#cite_note-Leonnig823-760">[755]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2018, Trump's former attorney Michael Cohen pleaded guilty to lying to Congress about Trump's 2016 attempts to reach a deal with Russia to build <a href="/wiki/Trump_Tower_Moscow" title="Trump Tower Moscow">a Trump Tower in Moscow</a>. Cohen said he had made the false statements on behalf of Trump, who was identified as "Individual-1" in the court documents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-761"><a href="#cite_note-761">[756]</a></sup>
</p><p>The five Trump associates who have pleaded guilty or have been convicted in Mueller's investigation or related cases include Paul Manafort, deputy campaign manager <a href="/wiki/Rick_Gates_(political_consultant)" title="Rick Gates (political consultant)">Rick Gates</a>, foreign policy advisor <a href="/wiki/George_Papadopoulos" title="George Papadopoulos">George Papadopoulos</a>, Michael Flynn, and Michael Cohen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-762"><a href="#cite_note-762">[757]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-763"><a href="#cite_note-763">[758]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2020, Trump campaign adviser <a href="/wiki/Roger_Stone" title="Roger Stone">Roger Stone</a> was sentenced to over three years in jail, after being convicted of lying to Congress and witness tampering regarding his attempts to learn more about hacked Democratic emails during the 2016 election. The sentencing judge said Stone "was prosecuted for covering up for the president".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP-200220_764-0"><a href="#cite_note-WP-200220-764">[759]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2019_congressional_investigation">2019 congressional investigation</span></h4>
<p>In March 2019, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_Judiciary_Committee" title="House Judiciary Committee">House Judiciary Committee</a> launched a broad investigation of Trump for possible obstruction of justice, corruption, and abuse of power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-765"><a href="#cite_note-765">[760]</a></sup> Committee chairman <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jerrold_Nadler" title="Jerrold Nadler">Jerrold Nadler</a> sent letters demanding documents to 81 individuals and organizations associated with Trump's presidency, business, and private life, saying it is "very clear that the president obstructed justice".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-766"><a href="#cite_note-766">[761]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fandos-190304_767-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fandos-190304-767">[762]</a></sup> Three other committee chairmen wrote the White House and State Department requesting details of Trump's communications with Putin, including any efforts to conceal the content of those communications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fandos-190304_767-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fandos-190304-767">[762]</a></sup> The White House refused to comply, asserting that presidential communications with foreign leaders are protected and confidential.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-768"><a href="#cite_note-768">[763]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judiciary">Judiciary</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_federal_judges_appointed_by_Donald_Trump" title="List of federal judges appointed by Donald Trump">List of federal judges appointed by Donald Trump</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_judicial_appointment_controversies" title="Donald Trump judicial appointment controversies">Donald Trump judicial appointment controversies</a></div>
<p>Trump has appointed more than 200 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_federal_judges" title="United States federal judges">federal judges</a> who were confirmed by the Senate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WheelerFriday_769-0"><a href="#cite_note-WheelerFriday-769">[764]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hulse_770-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hulse-770">[765]</a></sup> Senate Republicans, led by Senate Majority Leader <a href="/wiki/Mitch_McConnell" title="Mitch McConnell">Mitch McConnell</a>, have rapidly confirmed Trump's judicial appointees, usually against unified Democratic opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hulse_770-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hulse-770">[765]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ruiz_771-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ruiz-771">[766]</a></sup> Trump's appointments have shifted the federal judiciary to the <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ruiz_771-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ruiz-771">[766]</a></sup> Trump's judicial appointments have been overwhelmingly white men,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ruiz_771-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ruiz-771">[766]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cohen_772-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cohen-772">[767]</a></sup> and are younger on average than appointees by Trump's predecessors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ruiz_771-3"><a href="#cite_note-Ruiz-771">[766]</a></sup> Many are affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/Federalist_Society" title="Federalist Society">Federalist Society</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ruiz_771-4"><a href="#cite_note-Ruiz-771">[766]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has made three nominations to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court</a>: <a href="/wiki/Neil_Gorsuch" title="Neil Gorsuch">Neil Gorsuch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brett_Kavanaugh" title="Brett Kavanaugh">Brett Kavanaugh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Amy_Coney_Barrett" title="Amy Coney Barrett">Amy Coney Barrett</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barrett_773-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barrett-773">[768]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neil_Gorsuch_Supreme_Court_nomination" title="Neil Gorsuch Supreme Court nomination">Gorsuch was confirmed</a> in 2017 in a mostly <a href="/wiki/Party-line_vote" title="Party-line vote">party-line vote</a> of 54–45, after Republicans invoked the "<a href="/wiki/Nuclear_option" title="Nuclear option">nuclear option</a>" (a historic change to Senate rules removing the 60-vote threshold for advancing Supreme Court nominations) to defeat a Democratic <a href="/wiki/Filibuster" title="Filibuster">filibuster</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Caldwell_774-0"><a href="#cite_note-Caldwell-774">[769]</a></sup> Trump's predecessor <a href="/wiki/Merrick_Garland_Supreme_Court_nomination" title="Merrick Garland Supreme Court nomination">Obama had nominated</a> <a href="/wiki/Merrick_Garland" title="Merrick Garland">Merrick Garland</a> in 2016 to fill the vacancy, left by the death of <a href="/wiki/Antonin_Scalia" title="Antonin Scalia">Antonin Scalia</a>, but Senate Republicans under McConnell refused to consider the nomination in the last year of Obama's presidency, angering Democrats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Caldwell_774-1"><a href="#cite_note-Caldwell-774">[769]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brett_Kavanaugh_Supreme_Court_nomination" title="Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court nomination">Trump nominated Kavanaugh</a> in 2018 to replace retiring Justice <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Kennedy" title="Anthony Kennedy">Anthony Kennedy</a>; the Senate confirmed Kavanaugh in a mostly party-line vote of 50–48, after a bitter confirmation battle centered on <a href="/wiki/Christine_Blasey_Ford" title="Christine Blasey Ford">Christine Blasey Ford</a>'s allegation that Kavanaugh had attempted to rape her when they were teenagers, which Kavanaugh denied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-775"><a href="#cite_note-775">[770]</a></sup> In 2020, weeks before the elections, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Coney_Barrett_Supreme_Court_nomination" title="Amy Coney Barrett Supreme Court nomination">Trump nominated</a> <a href="/wiki/Amy_Coney_Barrett" title="Amy Coney Barrett">Amy Coney Barrett</a> to fill the vacancy left by the death of Justice <a href="/wiki/Ruth_Bader_Ginsburg" title="Ruth Bader Ginsburg">Ruth Bader Ginsburg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barrett_773-1"><a href="#cite_note-Barrett-773">[768]</a></sup> On October 26, 2020, the Senate voted 52–48 to confirm her nomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-776"><a href="#cite_note-776">[771]</a></sup>
</p><p>As president, Trump has disparaged courts and judges whom he disagrees with, often in personal terms, and has questioned the judiciary's constitutional authority. Trump's attacks on the courts have drawn rebukes from observers, including sitting federal judges, who are concerned about the effect of Trump's statements on the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_independence" title="Judicial independence">judicial independence</a> and public confidence in the judiciary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-777"><a href="#cite_note-777">[772]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OwnWords_778-0"><a href="#cite_note-OwnWords-778">[773]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-779"><a href="#cite_note-779">[774]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2020_presidential_election">2020 presidential election</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2020_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2020 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2020 presidential campaign</a> and <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020 United States presidential election</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_Postal_Service_crisis" title="2020 United States Postal Service crisis">2020 United States Postal Service crisis</a></div>
<p>Breaking with precedent, Trump filed to run for a second term with the FEC within a few hours of assuming the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-780"><a href="#cite_note-780">[775]</a></sup> Trump held his first re-election rally less than a month after taking office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-781"><a href="#cite_note-781">[776]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-782"><a href="#cite_note-782">[777]</a></sup> In his first two years in office, Trump's reelection committee reported raising $67.5 million, allowing him to begin 2019 with $19.3 million cash on hand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-783"><a href="#cite_note-783">[778]</a></sup> From the beginning of 2019 through July 2020, the Trump campaign and Republican Party raised $1.1 billion, but spent $800 million of that amount, evaporating their formerly large cash advantage over the Democratic nominee, former vice president <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-784"><a href="#cite_note-784">[779]</a></sup> The campaign's cash crunch forced a scale-back in advertising spending.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-785"><a href="#cite_note-785">[780]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_(50548265318).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2756" data-file-width="4134" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Donald_Trump_%2850548265318%29.jpg/220px-Donald_Trump_%2850548265318%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Donald_Trump_%2850548265318%29.jpg/330px-Donald_Trump_%2850548265318%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Donald_Trump_%2850548265318%29.jpg/440px-Donald_Trump_%2850548265318%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donald_Trump_(50548265318).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump in <a href="/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a> holding an official rally of his campaign</div></div></div>
<p>Starting in spring 2020, Trump began to sow doubts about the election, repeatedly claiming without evidence that the election would be "rigged"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Politico-Rigged_786-0"><a href="#cite_note-Politico-Rigged-786">[781]</a></sup> and expected widespread use of mail balloting would produce "massive election fraud".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Politico-Mail_787-0"><a href="#cite_note-Politico-Mail-787">[782]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-MailFraud_788-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-MailFraud-788">[783]</a></sup> In what <i>The New York Times</i> called an "extraordinary breach of presidential decorum", on July 30 Trump raised the idea of delaying the election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-200730_789-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-200730-789">[784]</a></sup> When in August the House of Representatives voted for a $25 billion grant to the U.S. Postal Service for the expected surge in mail voting, Trump blocked funding, saying he wanted to prevent any increase in voting by mail.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-790"><a href="#cite_note-790">[785]</a></sup> Trump became the <a href="/wiki/2020_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries" title="2020 Republican Party presidential primaries">Republican nominee</a> on August 24, 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-791"><a href="#cite_note-791">[786]</a></sup> He repeatedly refused to say whether he would accept the results of the election and commit to a <a href="/wiki/Peaceful_transition_of_power" title="Peaceful transition of power">peaceful transition of power</a> if he lost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-792"><a href="#cite_note-792">[787]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-793"><a href="#cite_note-793">[788]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump campaign advertisements focused on crime, claiming that cities would descend into lawlessness if his opponent, Biden, won the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-794"><a href="#cite_note-794">[789]</a></sup> Trump repeatedly misrepresented Biden's positions during the campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-795"><a href="#cite_note-795">[790]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-796"><a href="#cite_note-796">[791]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-797"><a href="#cite_note-797">[792]</a></sup> Trump's campaign message shifted to racist rhetoric in an attempt to reclaim voters lost from his base.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Allen-200709_798-0"><a href="#cite_note-Allen-200709-798">[793]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Costa_-200709_799-0"><a href="#cite_note-Costa_-200709-799">[794]</a></sup>
</p><p>Biden won the election, receiving 81.3 million votes (51.3%) to Trump's 74.2 million (46.8%)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vote2_800-0"><a href="#cite_note-vote2-800">[795]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vote1_801-0"><a href="#cite_note-vote1-801">[796]</a></sup> and winning the Electoral College by 306 to 232.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FormalizeBidenVictory_802-0"><a href="#cite_note-FormalizeBidenVictory-802">[797]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vote1_801-1"><a href="#cite_note-vote1-801">[796]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vote2_800-1"><a href="#cite_note-vote2-800">[795]</a></sup> U.S. election officials said the election was the "most secure" in U.S. history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_election_803-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_election-803">[798]</a></sup>
</p><p>At 2 a.m. the morning after the election, with the results still unclear, Trump declared victory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-804"><a href="#cite_note-804">[799]</a></sup> After Biden was projected the winner days later, Trump said, "this election is far from over" and baselessly alleged election fraud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USATODAY_election_805-0"><a href="#cite_note-USATODAY_election-805">[800]</a></sup> Trump and his allies filed dozens of legal challenges to the results, which were rejected by at least 86 judges from across the political spectrum, in both the <a href="/wiki/State_court_(United_States)" title="State court (United States)">state</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_federal_courts" title="United States federal courts">federal courts</a>, including by federal judges appointed by Trump himself. The courts found that Trump's claims had no factual or legal basis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-806"><a href="#cite_note-806">[801]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-807"><a href="#cite_note-807">[802]</a></sup> His legal team led by <a href="/wiki/Rudy_Giuliani" title="Rudy Giuliani">Rudy Giuliani</a> made numerous false and unsubstantiated assertions about an international communist conspiracy, rigged voting machines and polling place fraud to claim the election had been stolen from Trump.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-808"><a href="#cite_note-808">[803]</a></sup> Trump initially blocked government officials from cooperating in the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Joe_Biden" title="Presidential transition of Joe Biden">presidential transition of Joe Biden</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-809"><a href="#cite_note-809">[804]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-810"><a href="#cite_note-810">[805]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's allegations of widespread voting fraud were refuted by judges, state election officials, and his own administration's <a href="/wiki/Cybersecurity_and_Infrastructure_Security_Agency" title="Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency">Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency</a> (CISA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conclusive_811-0"><a href="#cite_note-conclusive-811">[806]</a></sup> After CISA director <a href="/wiki/Chris_Krebs" title="Chris Krebs">Chris Krebs</a> contradicted Trump's voting fraud allegations, Trump fired him on November 17.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_election_803-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_election-803">[798]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2020.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/ElectoralCollege2020.svg/290px-ElectoralCollege2020.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/ElectoralCollege2020.svg/435px-ElectoralCollege2020.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/ElectoralCollege2020.svg/580px-ElectoralCollege2020.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2020_with_results.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>2020 electoral vote results; Trump lost 232–306</div></div></div>
<p>With his post-election legal challenges to the election of Biden failing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-812"><a href="#cite_note-812">[807]</a></sup> Trump withdrew from public activities, drawing criticism that, given the surge in the pandemic, his retreat constituted irresponsible sulking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-813"><a href="#cite_note-813">[808]</a></sup> After three weeks of resistance, the administrator of the <a href="/wiki/General_Services_Administration" title="General Services Administration">General Services Administration</a> declared Biden the apparent winner of the election, allowing the disbursement of transition resources to his team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-814"><a href="#cite_note-814">[809]</a></sup> Trump still did not formally concede while claiming he recommended the GSA begin transition protocols.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-815"><a href="#cite_note-815">[810]</a></sup>
</p><p>He later said he would leave the White House if <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">the Electoral College</a> voted for Biden,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-816"><a href="#cite_note-816">[811]</a></sup> but he continued to try to subvert the results of the election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBC_election_817-0"><a href="#cite_note-NBC_election-817">[812]</a></sup> He personally communicated with various Republican local officials, state legislators, state attorneys general, a state governor, and federal legislators for help in overturning their election results, with one strategy aiming to replace certain states' presidential electors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-818"><a href="#cite_note-818">[813]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-819"><a href="#cite_note-819">[814]</a></sup> On December 11, 2020, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court" title="U.S. Supreme Court">U.S. Supreme Court</a> declined to hear <a href="/wiki/Texas_v._Pennsylvania" title="Texas v. Pennsylvania">a case filed by the Texas attorney general</a>, supported by Trump and his Republican allies, which asked the court to overturn the election results in four states won by Biden.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_820-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-820">[815]</a></sup> The Electoral College formalized Biden's victory on December 14, voting 306–232 as expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FormalizeBidenVictory_802-1"><a href="#cite_note-FormalizeBidenVictory-802">[797]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_profile">Public profile</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Approval_ratings">Approval ratings</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Opinion_polling_on_the_Donald_Trump_administration" title="Opinion polling on the Donald Trump administration">Opinion polling on the Donald Trump administration</a></div>
<p>At the end of Trump's second year, his two-year average Gallup approval rating was the lowest of any president since World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-821"><a href="#cite_note-821">[816]</a></sup> In January 2020, his Gallup rating reached 49%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-822"><a href="#cite_note-822">[817]</a></sup> the highest point since he took office, with 63% of those polled approving his handling of the economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-823"><a href="#cite_note-823">[818]</a></sup> His approval and disapproval ratings have been unusually stable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-824"><a href="#cite_note-824">[819]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-825"><a href="#cite_note-825">[820]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-826"><a href="#cite_note-826">[821]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Gallup%27s_most_admired_man_and_woman_poll" title="Gallup's most admired man and woman poll">Gallup's end-of-year poll</a> asking Americans to name the man they admire the most, Trump placed second to Obama in 2017 and 2018, and tied with Obama for most admired man in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gallup1678_827-0"><a href="#cite_note-gallup1678-827">[822]</a></sup> Since Gallup started conducting the poll in 1948,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tie_828-0"><a href="#cite_note-tie-828">[823]</a></sup> Trump is the first elected president not to be named most admired in his first year in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tie_828-1"><a href="#cite_note-tie-828">[823]</a></sup>
</p><p>Globally, a <a href="/wiki/Gallup_(company)" title="Gallup (company)">Gallup</a> poll on 134 countries comparing the approval ratings of U.S. leadership between the years 2016 and 2017 found that only in 29 of them did Trump lead Obama in job approval,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-829"><a href="#cite_note-829">[824]</a></sup> with more international respondents disapproving rather than approving of the Trump administration. Overall ratings were similar to those in the last two years of the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_W._Bush" title="Presidency of George W. Bush">George W. Bush presidency</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-830"><a href="#cite_note-830">[825]</a></sup> Only 16% of international respondents expressed confidence in Trump by mid-2020, according to a 13-nation <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Research" title="Pew Research">Pew Research</a> poll; this score was even lower than those of Russia's Vladimir Putin and China's Xi Jinping.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-831"><a href="#cite_note-831">[826]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_media">Social media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_on_social_media" title="Donald Trump on social media">Donald Trump on social media</a></div>
<p>Trump's presence on social media has attracted attention worldwide since he joined <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> in March 2009. He frequently tweeted during the 2016 election campaign and has continued to do so as president. As of October 2020, Trump has more than 85 million Twitter followers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-832"><a href="#cite_note-832">[827]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of May 2020, Trump had written about 52,000 tweets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCTweets_833-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCTweets-833">[828]</a></sup> These include 22,115 tweets over seven years before his presidential candidacy, 8,159 tweets during the <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math">1<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span> years of his candidacy and transition period, and 14,186 tweets over the first three years of his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-834"><a href="#cite_note-834">[829]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has frequently used Twitter as a direct means of communication with the public, sidelining the press.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-federalist-sidelining_835-0"><a href="#cite_note-federalist-sidelining-835">[830]</a></sup> A White House press secretary said early in his presidency that Trump's tweets are official statements by the president of the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-836"><a href="#cite_note-836">[831]</a></sup> employed for announcing policy or personnel changes. Trump used Twitter to fire Secretary of State Rex Tillerson in March 2018<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-837"><a href="#cite_note-837">[832]</a></sup> and Secretary of Defense Mark Esper in November 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-838"><a href="#cite_note-838">[833]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of Trump's tweets contain false assertions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20170427_839-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20170427-839">[834]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP-20170501_840-0"><a href="#cite_note-WP-20170501-840">[835]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CT-20170624_841-0"><a href="#cite_note-CT-20170624-841">[836]</a></sup>
In May 2020, Twitter began tagging some Trump tweets with fact-checking warnings<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCTweets_833-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBCTweets-833">[828]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Twitter_refutes_842-0"><a href="#cite_note-Twitter_refutes-842">[837]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-first_label_843-0"><a href="#cite_note-first_label-843">[838]</a></sup> and labels for violations of Twitter rules.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-second_label_844-0"><a href="#cite_note-second_label-844">[839]</a></sup> Trump responded by threatening to "strongly regulate" or "close down" social media platforms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCTweets_833-2"><a href="#cite_note-BBCTweets-833">[828]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lashing_out_845-0"><a href="#cite_note-lashing_out-845">[840]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="False_statements">False statements</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Veracity_of_statements_by_Donald_Trump" title="Veracity of statements by Donald Trump">Veracity of statements by Donald Trump</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1750" data-file-width="2775" decoding="async" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png/330px-2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png/495px-2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png/660px-2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2017-_Donald_Trump_veracity_-_composite_graph.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fact-checkers" title="Fact-checkers">Fact-checkers</a> from <i>The Washington Post</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kessler.FMC_846-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kessler.FMC-846">[841]</a></sup> the <i>Toronto Star</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TorontoStar_20190605_847-0"><a href="#cite_note-TorontoStar_20190605-847">[842]</a></sup> and CNN<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dale_20200309_848-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dale_20200309-848">[843]</a></sup> compiled data on "false or misleading claims" (orange background), and "false claims" (violet foreground), respectively.</div></div></div>
<p>As president, Trump has frequently made false statements in public speeches and remarks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20170427_839-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20170427-839">[834]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WP-20170501_840-1"><a href="#cite_note-WP-20170501-840">[835]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-849"><a href="#cite_note-849">[844]</a></sup> The misinformation has been documented by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fact-checker" title="Fact-checker">fact-checkers</a>; academics and the media have widely described the phenomenon as unprecedented in American politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unprecedenteduntruths_850-0"><a href="#cite_note-unprecedenteduntruths-850">[845]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Glasser-180803_851-0"><a href="#cite_note-Glasser-180803-851">[846]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Konnikova_247-1"><a href="#cite_note-Konnikova-247">[243]</a></sup> This behavior was similarly observed when he was a presidential candidate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-852"><a href="#cite_note-852">[847]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whoppers_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-whoppers-241">[237]</a></sup> His falsehoods have also become a distinctive part of his political identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Glasser-180803_851-1"><a href="#cite_note-Glasser-180803-851">[846]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump uttered "at least one false or misleading claim per day on 91 of his first 99 days" in office, according to <i>The New York Times</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20170427_839-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20170427-839">[834]</a></sup> and 1,318 total in his first 263 days in office, according to the "Fact Checker" political analysis column of <i>The Washington Post</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-853"><a href="#cite_note-853">[848]</a></sup> By the <i>Post</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s tally, it took Trump 601 days to reach 5,000 false or misleading statements and another 226 days to reach the 10,000 mark.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kessler-190429_854-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kessler-190429-854">[849]</a></sup> For the seven weeks leading up to the midterm elections, it rose to an average of thirty per day<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-855"><a href="#cite_note-855">[850]</a></sup> from 4.9 during his first hundred days in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-856"><a href="#cite_note-856">[851]</a></sup> The <i>Post</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s reported tally is 22,247 as of August 27, 2020,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kessler.FMC_846-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kessler.FMC-846">[841]</a></sup> with the 2019 total more than double the cumulative total of 2017 and 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-857"><a href="#cite_note-857">[852]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of Trump's falsehoods are inconsequential, such as his claims of a large crowd size during his inauguration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PolitiFact_1/21/2017_858-0"><a href="#cite_note-PolitiFact_1/21/2017-858">[853]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rein_3/6/2017_859-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rein_3/6/2017-859">[854]</a></sup> Others have had more far-reaching effects, such as Trump's promotion of unproven antimalarial drugs as a treatment for COVID‑19 in a press conference and on Twitter in March 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20200319washingtonpost_860-0"><a href="#cite_note-20200319washingtonpost-860">[855]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-M.Spring_861-0"><a href="#cite_note-M.Spring-861">[856]</a></sup> The claims had consequences worldwide, such as a shortage of these drugs in the United States and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Panic-buying" title="Panic-buying">panic-buying</a> in Africa and South Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20200323washingtonpost_862-0"><a href="#cite_note-20200323washingtonpost-862">[857]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsj1158498189_863-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsj1158498189-863">[858]</a></sup> The state of <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a> obtained nearly a million doses for its hospitals, even though most of them did not want the drug.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atterbury-Dixon_864-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atterbury-Dixon-864">[859]</a></sup> Other misinformation, such as Trump's retweet of unverified videos produced by far-right fascist <a href="/wiki/Jayda_Fransen" title="Jayda Fransen">Jayda Fransen</a> in November 2017, serves Trump's domestic political purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AZurcher_865-0"><a href="#cite_note-AZurcher-865">[860]</a></sup> As a matter of principle, Trump does not apologize for his falsehoods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JAllen_866-0"><a href="#cite_note-JAllen-866">[861]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite the frequency of Trump's falsehoods, the media rarely referred to them as "lies",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DGreenberg_867-0"><a href="#cite_note-DGreenberg-867">[862]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DBouder_868-0"><a href="#cite_note-DBouder-868">[863]</a></sup> a word that has in the past been avoided out of respect for the presidential office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DGreenberg_867-1"><a href="#cite_note-DGreenberg-867">[862]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DBouder_868-1"><a href="#cite_note-DBouder-868">[863]</a></sup> Nevertheless, in August 2018 <i>The Washington Post</i> declared for the first time that some of Trump's misstatements (statements concerning hush money paid to <a href="/wiki/Stormy_Daniels" title="Stormy Daniels">Stormy Daniels</a> and <i>Playboy</i> model <a href="/wiki/Karen_McDougal" title="Karen McDougal">Karen McDougal</a>) were lies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GKessler_869-0"><a href="#cite_note-GKessler-869">[864]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DBouder_868-2"><a href="#cite_note-DBouder-868">[863]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2020, Trump was a significant source of disinformation on national voting practices and the COVID-19 virus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Politico-Mail_787-1"><a href="#cite_note-Politico-Mail-787">[782]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-MailFraud_788-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-MailFraud-788">[783]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAT-Disinfo_870-0"><a href="#cite_note-USAT-Disinfo-870">[865]</a></sup>  Trump's attacks on mail-in ballots and other election practices served to weaken public faith in the integrity of the 2020 presidential election,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Politico-Rigged_786-1"><a href="#cite_note-Politico-Rigged-786">[781]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-Elections_871-0"><a href="#cite_note-AP-Elections-871">[866]</a></sup> while his disinformation about the pandemic dangerously delayed and weakened the national response to it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAT-Disinfo_870-1"><a href="#cite_note-USAT-Disinfo-870">[865]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_4_11_20_628-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_4_11_20-628">[623]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time-BeatIt_872-0"><a href="#cite_note-Time-BeatIt-872">[867]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some view the nature and frequency of Trump's falsehoods as having profound and corrosive consequences on democracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTomasky_873-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTomasky-873">[868]</a></sup> James Pfiffner, professor of policy and government at George Mason University, wrote in 2019 that Trump lies differently from previous presidents, because he offers "egregious false statements that are demonstrably contrary to well-known facts"; these lies are the "most important" of all Trump lies. By calling facts into question, people will be unable to properly evaluate their government, with beliefs or policy irrationally settled by "political power"; this erodes <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democracy</a>, wrote Pfiffner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pfiffner_874-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pfiffner-874">[869]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Promotion_of_conspiracy_theories">Promotion of conspiracy theories</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_conspiracy_theories_promoted_by_Donald_Trump" title="List of conspiracy theories promoted by Donald Trump">List of conspiracy theories promoted by Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Before and throughout his presidency, Trump has promoted numerous conspiracy theories, including "<a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_citizenship_conspiracy_theories" title="Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories">birtherism</a>", the <a href="/wiki/Clinton_Body_Count" title="Clinton Body Count">Clinton Body Count</a> theory, <a href="/wiki/QAnon" title="QAnon">QAnon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Conspiracy_theories_related_to_the_Trump%E2%80%93Ukraine_scandal" title="Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal">alleged Ukrainian interference in U.S. elections</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-875"><a href="#cite_note-875">[870]</a></sup> In October 2020, Trump retweeted a QAnon follower who asserted that <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a> was still alive, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Body_double" title="Body double">body double</a> had been killed in his place and "Biden and Obama may have had <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seal_Team_6" title="Seal Team 6">Seal Team 6</a> killed."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-876"><a href="#cite_note-876">[871]</a></sup>
</p><p>During and since the <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election" title="2020 United States presidential election">2020 United States presidential election</a>, Trump has promoted various conspiracy theories for his defeat including the “dead voter” conspiracy theory,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-877"><a href="#cite_note-877">[872]</a></sup> and that without providing any evidence he has made other conspiracy theories such as that “some states allowed voters to turn in ballots after Election Day; that vote-counting machines were rigged to favour Mr Biden; and even that the FBI, the Justice Department and the federal court system were complicit in an attempt to cover up election fraud.”<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-878"><a href="#cite_note-878">[873]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationship_with_the_press">Relationship with the press</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Donald_Trump#Relationship_with_the_news_media" title="Presidency of Donald Trump">Presidency of Donald Trump § Relationship with the news media</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_(33573172373).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_%2833573172373%29.jpg/220px-President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_%2833573172373%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_%2833573172373%29.jpg/330px-President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_%2833573172373%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_%2833573172373%29.jpg/440px-President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_%2833573172373%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Trump%27s_First_100_Days-_45_(33573172373).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trump talking to the press, March 2017</div></div></div>
<p>Throughout his career, Trump has sought media attention, with a "love-hate" relationship with the press.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parnes_879-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parnes-879">[874]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ingram-160301_880-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ingram-160301-880">[875]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AN-170124_881-0"><a href="#cite_note-AN-170124-881">[876]</a></sup> Trump began promoting himself in the press in the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dantonio-160710_882-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dantonio-160710-882">[877]</a></sup> Fox News anchor <a href="/wiki/Bret_Baier" title="Bret Baier">Bret Baier</a> and former House speaker <a href="/wiki/Paul_Ryan" title="Paul Ryan">Paul Ryan</a> have characterized Trump as a "<a href="/wiki/Internet_troll" title="Internet troll">troll</a>" who makes controversial statements to see people's "heads explode".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-883"><a href="#cite_note-883">[878]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-884"><a href="#cite_note-884">[879]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2016 campaign, Trump benefited from a record amount of free media coverage, elevating his standing in the Republican primaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cillizza-160614_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cillizza-160614-240">[236]</a></sup> <i>New York Times</i> writer <a href="/wiki/Amy_Chozick" title="Amy Chozick">Amy Chozick</a> wrote in 2018 that Trump's media dominance, which enthralls the public and creates "can't miss" <a href="/wiki/Reality_television" title="Reality television">reality television</a>-type coverage, was politically beneficial for him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChozickNYT_885-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChozickNYT-885">[880]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout his 2016 presidential campaign and his presidency, Trump has accused the press of bias, calling it the "fake news media" and "the <a href="/wiki/Enemy_of_the_people" title="Enemy of the people">enemy of the people</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Walsh-160724_237-1"><a href="#cite_note-Walsh-160724-237">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-886"><a href="#cite_note-886">[881]</a></sup> After winning the election, journalist <a href="/wiki/Lesley_Stahl" title="Lesley Stahl">Lesley Stahl</a> recounted Trump's saying he intentionally demeaned and discredited the media "so when you write negative stories about me no one will believe you."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-887"><a href="#cite_note-887">[882]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has privately and publicly mused about revoking the press credentials of journalists he views as critical.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:17_888-0"><a href="#cite_note-:17-888">[883]</a></sup> His administration moved to revoke the press passes of two White House reporters, which were restored by the courts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_889-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-889">[884]</a></sup> In 2019, a member of the foreign press reported many of the same concerns as those of media in the U.S., expressing concern that a normalization process by reporters and media results in an inaccurate characterization of Trump.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-890"><a href="#cite_note-890">[885]</a></sup> The Trump White House held about a hundred formal press briefings in 2017, declining by half during 2018 and to two in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_889-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-889">[884]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump has employed the legal system as an intimidation tactic against the press.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlantic_Press_891-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic_Press-891">[886]</a></sup> In early 2020, the Trump campaign sued <i>The New York Times</i>, <i>The Washington Post</i>, and CNN for alleged defamation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-892"><a href="#cite_note-892">[887]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-893"><a href="#cite_note-893">[888]</a></sup> These lawsuits lacked merit and were not likely to succeed, however.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlantic_Press_891-1"><a href="#cite_note-Atlantic_Press-891">[886]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheHill_Press_894-0"><a href="#cite_note-TheHill_Press-894">[889]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Racial_views">Racial views</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Racial_views_of_Donald_Trump" title="Racial views of Donald Trump">Racial views of Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>Many of Trump's comments and actions have been seen as racially charged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-895"><a href="#cite_note-895">[890]</a></sup> He has repeatedly denied he is racist, asserting: "I am the least racist person there is anywhere in the world."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-896"><a href="#cite_note-896">[891]</a></sup> Many of his supporters say the way he speaks reflects his rejection of <a href="/wiki/Political_correctness" title="Political correctness">political correctness</a>, while others accept it because they share such beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-897"><a href="#cite_note-897">[892]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nation-20170508_898-0"><a href="#cite_note-nation-20170508-898">[893]</a></sup> Scholars have discussed Trump's rhetoric in the context of <a href="/wiki/White_supremacy" title="White supremacy">white supremacy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-899"><a href="#cite_note-899">[894]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several studies and surveys have found that racist attitudes fueled Trump's political ascendance and have been more important than economic factors in determining the allegiance of Trump voters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nation-20170508_898-1"><a href="#cite_note-nation-20170508-898">[893]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vox-20171215_900-0"><a href="#cite_note-vox-20171215-900">[895]</a></sup> Racist and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamophobic" title="Islamophobic">Islamophobic</a> attitudes have been shown to be a powerful indicator of support for Trump.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-901"><a href="#cite_note-901">[896]</a></sup> In national polling, about half of Americans say that Trump is racist; a greater proportion believe that he has emboldened racists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marcin_902-0"><a href="#cite_note-Marcin-902">[897]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Quinnipiac-180703_903-0"><a href="#cite_note-Quinnipiac-180703-903">[898]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-904"><a href="#cite_note-904">[899]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1975, he settled a 1973 Department of Justice lawsuit that alleged housing discrimination against black renters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mahler_81-2"><a href="#cite_note-Mahler-81">[77]</a></sup> He has also been accused of racism for insisting a group of black and Latino teenagers were guilty of raping a white woman in the 1989 <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_jogger_case" title="Central Park jogger case">Central Park jogger case</a>, even after they were exonerated by DNA evidence in 2002. He has maintained his position on the matter into 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-905"><a href="#cite_note-905">[900]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump relaunched his political career in 2011 as a leading proponent of <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama_citizenship_conspiracy_theories" title="Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories">"birther" conspiracy theories</a> alleging that Barack Obama, the first black U.S. president, was not born in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-906"><a href="#cite_note-906">[901]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-907"><a href="#cite_note-907">[902]</a></sup> In April 2011, Trump claimed credit for pressuring the White House to publish the "long-form" birth certificate, which he considered fraudulent, and later saying this made him "very popular".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Madison27April_908-0"><a href="#cite_note-Madison27April-908">[903]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-909"><a href="#cite_note-909">[904]</a></sup> In September 2016, amid pressure, he acknowledged that Obama was born in the U.S. and falsely claimed the rumors had been started by <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton" title="Hillary Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a> during <a href="/wiki/Hillary_Clinton_2008_presidential_campaign" title="Hillary Clinton 2008 presidential campaign">her 2008 presidential campaign</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-drops_910-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-drops-910">[905]</a></sup> In 2017, he reportedly still expressed birther views in private.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-911"><a href="#cite_note-911">[906]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to an analysis in <i><a href="/wiki/Political_Science_Quarterly" title="Political Science Quarterly">Political Science Quarterly</a></i>, Trump made "explicitly racist appeals to whites" during his 2016 presidential campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-912"><a href="#cite_note-912">[907]</a></sup> In particular, his campaign launch speech drew widespread criticism for claiming Mexican immigrants were "bringing drugs, they're bringing crime, they're rapists."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-913"><a href="#cite_note-913">[908]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-914"><a href="#cite_note-914">[909]</a></sup> His later comments about a Mexican-American judge presiding over a civil suit regarding <a href="/wiki/Trump_University" title="Trump University">Trump University</a> were also criticized as racist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-915"><a href="#cite_note-915">[910]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><div class="PopUpMediaTransform" id="mwe_player_0" style="width:220px;" videopayload='&lt;div class="mediaContainer" style="width:854px"&gt;&lt;video id="mwe_player_1" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm/854px--President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" autoplay="" style="width:854px;height:480px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="1401.072" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/1/14/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm.480p.vp9.webm#t=00:13:11" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="319488" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/1/14/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm.360p.vp9.webm#t=00:13:11" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-bandwidth="479216" data-framerate="29.97"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/1/14/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm/President_Trump_Gives_a_Statement_on_the_Infrastructure_Discussion.webm.360p.webm#t=00:13:11" type="video/webm; <p>Trump's comments in reaction to the <a href="/wiki/Unite_the_Right_rally" title="Unite the Right rally">2017 Charlottesville far-right rally</a> were interpreted by some as implying a <a href="/wiki/Moral_equivalence" title="Moral equivalence">moral equivalence</a> between white supremacist demonstrators and counter-protesters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-916"><a href="#cite_note-916">[911]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a January 2018 <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">Oval Office</a> meeting to discuss immigration legislation, he reportedly referred to El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, and African nations as "shithole countries".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zack_917-0"><a href="#cite_note-zack-917">[912]</a></sup> His remarks were condemned as racist worldwide, as well as by many members of Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-918"><a href="#cite_note-918">[913]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-919"><a href="#cite_note-919">[914]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2019, Trump tweeted that four Democratic members of Congress – all four minority women, three of them native-born Americans – should "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Go_back_where_you_came_from" title="Go back where you came from">go back</a>" to the countries they "came from".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-920"><a href="#cite_note-920">[915]</a></sup> Two days later the House of Representatives voted 240–187, mostly along party lines, to condemn his "racist comments".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-921"><a href="#cite_note-921">[916]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_nationalist" title="White nationalist">White nationalist</a> publications and social media sites praised his remarks, which continued over the following days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-922"><a href="#cite_note-922">[917]</a></sup> Trump continued to make similar remarks during his 2020 campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-923"><a href="#cite_note-923">[918]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Misogyny_and_allegations_of_sexual_assault_and_misconduct">Misogyny and allegations of sexual assault and misconduct</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_sexual_misconduct_allegations" title="Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations">Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations</a></div>
<p>Trump has a history of insulting and belittling women when speaking to media and in tweet. He made lewd comments, demeaned women's looks, and called them names like 'dog', 'crazed, crying lowlife', 'face of a pig', or 'horseface'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes_Trump_insults_924-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes_Trump_insults-924">[919]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Trump_talks_925-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Trump_talks-925">[920]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-926"><a href="#cite_note-926">[921]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2016, two days before the <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_debates#Second_presidential_debate_(Washington_University_in_St._Louis)" title="2016 United States presidential debates">second presidential debate</a>, a 2005 "<a href="/wiki/Hot_mic" title="Hot mic">hot mic</a>" <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_Access_Hollywood_tape" title="Donald Trump Access Hollywood tape">recording</a> surfaced in which Trump was heard bragging about kissing and groping women without their consent, saying "when you're a star, they let you do it, you can do anything ... grab 'em by the <a href="/wiki/Pussy#Female_genitalia" title="Pussy">pussy</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBC080716_927-0"><a href="#cite_note-NBC080716-927">[922]</a></sup> The incident's widespread media exposure led to Trump's first public apology during the campaign<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-928"><a href="#cite_note-928">[923]</a></sup> and caused outrage across the political spectrum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-929"><a href="#cite_note-929">[924]</a></sup>
</p><p>At least twenty-six women have publicly accused Trump of sexual misconduct as of September 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Donald_Trump&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, including his then-wife Ivana. There were allegations of rape, violence, being kissed and groped without consent, looking under women's skirts, and walking in on naked women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-930"><a href="#cite_note-930">[925]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-931"><a href="#cite_note-931">[926]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-932"><a href="#cite_note-932">[927]</a></sup> In 2016, he denied all accusations, calling them "false smears", and alleged there was a conspiracy against him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-933"><a href="#cite_note-933">[928]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Allegations_of_inciting_violence">Allegations of inciting violence</span></h3>
<p>Some research suggests Trump's rhetoric causes an increased incidence of hate crimes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-934"><a href="#cite_note-934">[929]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-935"><a href="#cite_note-935">[930]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-936"><a href="#cite_note-936">[931]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2016_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign">2016 campaign</a>, he urged or praised physical attacks against protesters or reporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-937"><a href="#cite_note-937">[932]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-938"><a href="#cite_note-938">[933]</a></sup> Since then, some defendants prosecuted for hate crimes or violent acts cited Trump's rhetoric in arguing that they were not culpable or should receive a lighter sentence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-939"><a href="#cite_note-939">[934]</a></sup> In August 2019 it was reported that a man who allegedly assaulted a minor for perceived disrespect toward the national anthem had cited Trump's rhetoric in his own defense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-940"><a href="#cite_note-940">[935]</a></sup> In August 2019, a nationwide review by ABC News identified at least 36 criminal cases in which Trump was invoked in direct connection with violence or threats of violence. Of these, 29 were based around someone echoing presidential rhetoric, while the other seven were someone protesting it or not having direct linkage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-941"><a href="#cite_note-941">[936]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_culture">Popular culture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_in_popular_culture" title="Donald Trump in popular culture">Donald Trump in popular culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_in_music" title="Donald Trump in music">Donald Trump in music</a></div>
<p>Trump has been the subject of parody, comedy, and caricature. He has been parodied regularly on <a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live_parodies_of_Donald_Trump" title="Saturday Night Live parodies of Donald Trump"><i>Saturday Night Live</i></a> by <a href="/wiki/Phil_Hartman" title="Phil Hartman">Phil Hartman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Darrell_Hammond" title="Darrell Hammond">Darrell Hammond</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alec_Baldwin" title="Alec Baldwin">Alec Baldwin</a>, and in <i><a href="/wiki/South_Park" title="South Park">South Park</a></i> as <a href="/wiki/Mr._Garrison" title="Mr. Garrison">Mr. Garrison</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Simpsons" title="The Simpsons">The Simpsons</a></i> episode "<a href="/wiki/Bart_to_the_Future" title="Bart to the Future">Bart to the Future</a>" – written during his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2000" title="Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000">2000 campaign for the Reform Party</a> – anticipated a Trump presidency. A parody series called <i><a href="/wiki/The_President_Show" title="The President Show">The President Show</a></i> debuted in April 2017 on <a href="/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a>, while another one called <i><a href="/wiki/Our_Cartoon_President" title="Our Cartoon President">Our Cartoon President</a></i> debuted on <a href="/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a> in February 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-942"><a href="#cite_note-942">[937]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trump's wealth and lifestyle had been a fixture of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hip-hop" title="Hip-hop">hip-hop</a> lyrics since the 1980s; he was named in hundreds of songs, most often in a positive tone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538-hiphop_943-0"><a href="#cite_note-538-hiphop-943">[938]</a></sup> Mentions of Trump in hip-hop turned negative and pejorative after he ran for office in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538-hiphop_943-1"><a href="#cite_note-538-hiphop-943">[938]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Recognition">Recognition</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_honors_and_awards_received_by_Donald_Trump" title="List of honors and awards received by Donald Trump">List of honors and awards received by Donald Trump</a></div>
<p>In 1983, Trump received the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_National_Fund_Tree_of_Life_Award" title="Jewish National Fund Tree of Life Award">Jewish National Fund Tree of Life Award</a>, after he helped fund two playgrounds, a park, and a reservoir in Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-944"><a href="#cite_note-944">[939]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_945-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-945">[940]</a></sup> In 1986, he received the <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island_Medal_of_Honor" title="Ellis Island Medal of Honor">Ellis Island Medal of Honor</a> in recognition of "patriotism, tolerance, brotherhood and diversity",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-946"><a href="#cite_note-946">[941]</a></sup> and in 1995 was awarded the President's Medal from the <a href="/wiki/Freedoms_Foundation" title="Freedoms Foundation">Freedoms Foundation</a> for his support of youth programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-947"><a href="#cite_note-947">[942]</a></sup> He has been awarded five honorary doctorates, but one was revoked by <a href="/wiki/Robert_Gordon_University" title="Robert Gordon University">Robert Gordon University</a> in 2015 after Trump called for a Muslim ban, citing Trump's speech being "wholly incompatible<span class="nowrap"> </span>... with the ethos and values of the university". The remaining awards are <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_University" title="Lehigh University">Lehigh University</a>'s honorary doctorate of laws in 1988, <a href="/wiki/Wagner_College" title="Wagner College">Wagner College</a>'s honorary doctorate of humane letters in 2004, and <a href="/wiki/Liberty_University" title="Liberty University">Liberty University</a>'s honorary doctorates of business and law in 2012 and 2017 respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-948"><a href="#cite_note-948">[943]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2016, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> named Trump as its "<a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year">Person of the Year</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PersonYear_949-0"><a href="#cite_note-PersonYear-949">[944]</a></sup> but Trump took issue with the magazine for referring to him as the "President of the Divided States of America".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-950"><a href="#cite_note-950">[945]</a></sup> In the same month, he was named <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Financial_Times_Person_of_the_Year" title="Financial Times Person of the Year">Person of the Year</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FT_2016_951-0"><a href="#cite_note-FT_2016-951">[946]</a></sup> and was ranked by <i>Forbes</i> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forbes_list_of_The_World%27s_Most_Powerful_People" title="Forbes list of The World's Most Powerful People">second most powerful person in the world</a> after <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-952"><a href="#cite_note-952">[947]</a></sup> As president, Trump received the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_King_Abdulaziz" title="Order of King Abdulaziz">Collar of The Order of Abdulaziz al Saud</a> from Saudi Arabia in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-953"><a href="#cite_note-953">[948]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-electoral-college-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-electoral-college_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Presidential elections in the United States are decided by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">Electoral College</a>. Each state names a number of electors equal to its representation in <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a>, and (in most states) all delegates vote for the winner of the local state vote. Consequently, it is possible for the <a href="/wiki/President-elect_of_the_United_States" title="President-elect of the United States">president-elect</a> to have received fewer votes from the country's total population (the popular vote). This situation has occurred <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_elections_in_which_the_winner_lost_the_popular_vote" title="United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote">five times since 1824</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-age-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-age_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-age_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> was older upon his second-term inauguration, and upon being inaugurated in 2021, President-elect <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> will replace both as the oldest president ever to serve.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oldest_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-oldest-2">[1]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-coordination-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-coordination_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mueller, Robert (March 2019). <a class="external text" href="https://www.justice.gov/storage/report.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Report on the Investigation into Russian Interference in the 2016 Presidential Election"</a>. <b>I</b>. p. 2. "In connection with that analysis, we addressed the factual question whether members of the Trump Campaign 'coordinat[ed]' – a term that appears in the appointment order – with Russian election interference activities. Like collusion, 'coordination' does not have a settled definition in federal criminal law. We understood coordination to require an agreement – tacit or express – between the Trump Campaign and the Russian government on election interference. That requires more than the two parties taking actions that were informed by or responsive to the other's actions or interests. We applied the term coordination in that sense when stating in the report that the investigation did not establish that the Trump campaign coordinated with the Russian government in its election interference activities." </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Wealth-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Wealth_59-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This estimate is by <i>Forbes</i> in their annual ranking. <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Billionaires_Index" title="Bloomberg Billionaires Index">Bloomberg Billionaires Index</a> listed Trump's net worth as $2.97 billion in June 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBI_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBI-57">[54]</a></sup> and Wealth-X listed it as at least $3.2 billion in April 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WX_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-WX-58">[55]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-285"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-285">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Records on this matter date from the year 1824. The number "five" includes the elections of <a href="/wiki/1824_United_States_presidential_election" title="1824 United States presidential election">1824</a>, <a href="/wiki/1876_United_States_presidential_election" title="1876 United States presidential election">1876</a>, <a href="/wiki/1888_United_States_presidential_election" title="1888 United States presidential election">1888</a>, <a href="/wiki/2000_United_States_presidential_election" title="2000 United States presidential election">2000</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election" title="2016 United States presidential election">2016</a>. Despite their similarities, some of these five elections had peculiar results; e.g. <a href="/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams" title="John Quincy Adams">John Quincy Adams</a> trailed in <i>both</i> the national popular vote and the Electoral College in 1824 (since no one had a majority in the Electoral College, Adams was chosen by the House of Representatives), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samuel_Tilden" title="Samuel Tilden">Samuel Tilden</a> in 1876 remains the only losing candidate to win an actual majority of the popular vote (rather than just a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_(voting)" title="Plurality (voting)">plurality</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[280]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFViser2015">Viser, Matt (August 28, 2015). <a class="external text" href="https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/08/28/donald-trump-was-bombastic-even-wharton-business-school/3FO0j1uS5X6S8156yH3YhL/story.html" rel="nofollow">"Even in college, Donald Trump was brash"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Boston_Globe" title="The Boston Globe">The Boston Globe</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSelk2018">Selk, Avi (May 20, 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2018/05/20/its-the-50th-anniversary-of-the-day-trump-left-college-and-nearly-had-to-go-to-war/" rel="nofollow">"It's the 50th anniversary of the day Trump left college and (briefly) faced the draft"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 3,</span> 2019</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Washington+Post&amp;rft.atitle=It%27s+the+50th+anniversary+of+the+day+Trump+left+college+and+%28briefly%29+faced+the+draft&amp;rft.date=2018-05-20&amp;rft.aulast=Selk&amp;rft.aufirst=Avi&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fnews%2Fretropolis%2Fwp%2F2018%2F05%2F20%2Fits-the-50th-anniversary-of-the-day-trump-left-college-and-nearly-had-to-go-to-war%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ADonald+Trump"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFAshford2019">Ashford, Grace (February 27, 2019). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/27/us/politics/trump-school-grades.html" rel="nofollow">"Michael Cohen Says Trump Told Him to Threaten Schools Not to Release Grades"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFWalsh2018">Walsh, John (October 3, 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-forbes-wealthiest-people-in-the-us-list-2018-10" rel="nofollow">"Trump has fallen 138 spots on Forbes' wealthiest-Americans list, his net worth down over $1 billion, since he announced his presidential bid in 2015"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Business_Insider" title="Business Insider">Business Insider</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">.
